awd_titl_txt: CPS:Medium:Foundations of Secure Cyber Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Cyber-physical systems regulating critical infrastructures, such as electrical grids and water networks, are increasingly geographically distributed, necessitating communication between remote sensors, actuators and controllers.  The combination of networked computational and physical subsystems leads to new security vulnerabilities that adversaries can exploit with devastating consequences.  A synchronized attack on the interdependent network components and physical plants can create complex and new security vulnerabilities that cannot be addressed by securing the constituent systems individually.

This project takes a holistic view by utilizing the properties of physical systems to design new secure protocols and architectures for cyber-physical systems (CPS) through a unified conceptual framework, which uses models for the physical system and the communication/computation network to define precise attack models and vulnerabilities. These mathematical models are used to design algorithms and protocols with provable operational security guarantees, thus enabling the design of more trustworthy architectures and components. The algorithms, protocols, and architectures are validated on CPS testbeds targeting building, automobile, and smart-grid applications. Additionally, the research is being integrated into the curriculum via the creation of novel coursework combining the underlying control, information theory, cryptography, and embedded system concepts.

By improving the protection of critical cyber-physical infrastructure against emerging threats, this research is expected to provide direct socio-economic benefits, ranging from individual organizations to a national scale. The inter-disciplinary team of this project will integrate teaching and curriculum development with the research, contributing to the training of a new generation of engineers well versed in the design of trustworthy cyber-physical systems.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

We are increasingly relying on cyber-physical systems (CPS). Such systems range from critical infrastructure (like electric grids), to consumer devices (smart homes enabled by so-called IoT or Internet-of-Things), to medical devices (like pacemakers, insulin pumps), and to automated transportation (self-driving cars, drones etc). The combination of networked computational and physical subsystems leads to new security vulnerabilities that adversaries can exploit with devastating consequences.

This project was one of the first efforts to do a foundational examination of the security of cyber-physical systems. One of the basic principles we demonstrated was that security of CPS goes beyond information-security, and one needs to develop holistic defense techniques that are enabled by using physical dynamics along with information/cyber security. We believe that we met the goals of the project to formally define an attack model for secure CPS and defense objectives; develop the theory and secure protocols for safely operating the CPS despite adversarial attacks and developing an experimental evaluation/validation of secure CPS systems for several applications.

Intellectual merit:

Scientific accomplishments: There were many new scientific results that were discovered and published during the course of this project, with details in the publications as well as summarized in annual reports of the project. We would like to highlight one aspect of the scientific contributions.

In order to control a physical system (say an automobile), one needs to estimate the state of the system through sensing various aspects (think of anti-skidding control, which needs to know wheel speeds). If some of these sensors themselves are attacked, then a question is how to still manage to operate the CPS under such attacks. We observed that an adversary could spoof/alter sensors, but cannot change the physics, and therefore using physical dynamics, one can in many cases operate the system as desired, despite adversarial attacks. We have developed not only the theory for such an approach, but also implementable algorithms, as well as validations on small testbeds (which were incorporated in to a DARPA program). One can also ask whether we can make the sensing process itself more secure to adversarial attacks. We demonstrated a new secure sensing mechanism for a class of active sensors (where the environment's response to a probing signal enables sensing). This type of sensors are commonly used in ABS in automobiles, and we gave a proof of-concept demonstration that one can make such sensors more secure by designing the probing signals and the processing, and not changing the sensing operation itself. Again, this critically used the physical dynamics to enable security.  There were many more scientific accomplishments on topics of security and privacy of CPS, such as protecting captured devices through software obfuscation, developing cryptographic methods for detecting malware in software, identifying and controlling systems despite attacks etc., which can be found in our annual reports and publications.


Scientific impact: One measure of academic impact of the project is the number of publications during the duration of the project; this project had over 60 publications in top-tier conferences and journals in the areas of CPS systems and security. The work was also disseminated through several invited lectures in various industrial and academic settings by the PIs. Another aspect is the scientific recognition through awards as well as press coverage; several papers supported by this project received best paper awards in top-tier conferences of ACM and IEEE and work done in this project was reported in several popular publications including Wired Magazine.  The scientific impact could also be seen through citations of work and followup to our results. For example, a foundational paper on secure state estimation and control which was published in 2014 (in IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control) has already received about 130 citations (according to Google Scholar). An important aspect is of impact through scientific training. The project supported research of about 8 graduate students, several of whom did their PhDs on topics of the project, and about 3 postdoctoral scholars were supported for different durations during the course of this project.  The work done in this project was also transformative in DoD and industrial applications, e.g., ideas from the project were used in the DARPA HACMS program.

Broader impact:

Security attacks on various CPS, from electric grids to autonomous vehicles to medical devices have recently reached popular press. These attacks can have devastating human and societal consequences, and therefore defenses against such security threats is critical. In this project, we have developed a scientific framework with which one can start to develop defenses against such attacks. These defenses can not only have significant security benefits, but could potentially enable more widespread use of such technology, which could also have an economic impact. We also integrated several ideas from this project into the curriculum through the courses taught at UCLA.
